title: How to write 1000 words in a day - Quora

response.answer_text: ‘What are some good strategies for writing thousands of words in a day?’ I write quickly and could go on for hours until I’m forced to call it a day. I’m assuming here that we are talking about writing novels? I’ve done this for all my novels. And usually write more than 4 or 5 chapters a day. Each chapter depending on what I want to say is usually more than 10–15 pages. What’s the trick? You need to have an idea of what you want to say in each chapter. Some writers find doing an outline or pre-plan helpful. Very rarely have I jacked an entire chapter because it didn’t work. Having said that I often go for months thinking about ideas, dialogue, narration and background story etc before I’m ready to commit this to paper. I am unable to write 1000 words or more if I have not prepared my story or characters. Reading a lot and generally knowing a lot about what you want to say is the best option. (This includes emotions of characters, thoughts and background noise etc. I’ve only ever suffered writers block once when I first started writing). Which is why writers are often advised to write about what you know. A way out this quandary (since knowing about certain facts outside your own life experiences) would be to do a lot of research. Writing is intensely pleasurable. And once you start writing, it would be impossible to do anything else. You feel as if you want to die if you didn’t write. Like breathing, you can’t do without it. But the agony of writing is when you have finally finished that first draft (I’ve only ever done one draft by the way, and just edit edit edit like there’s no tomorrow!) then find you want to share your true genius with the world - but can’t find an agent to represent your work. Torture! Absolute torture! Have faith in your writing and keep going. Keep practicing until you get better and better. I always believed that true talent that is not shared with the world is their loss. Not yours. Sooner or later, if your work has true merit, it will come to light. And this coming from someone who was denied the opportunity to study Creative Writing at University from literally every university in England, despite achieving a first in both EngIish and English Lit at O’Level. I remember applying 3 times, in 3 consecutive years. To no avail. I was a mature student with no refs. I tried again and again but got nowhere. In the end I came across Stephen Kings ‘On Writing’ and studied that. Downloaded it and read it blue. I also got a lot of direction from other writers online who posted stuff on their blogs. Very helpful. In my last attempt to study writing at university which I did through UCAS, only 2 uni’s bothered to reply to my application. And so on and so forth… the point I’m trying to say is that 1000 words is a doddle if you know what you want to say. And how you want to say it. The Art of Writing (Novels) ought to be (for me, at least) based on how beautiful your prose, and how well you articulate your ideas. Finally, I am always amazed at how most writers on Quora are able to keep me engaged in their stories. I loose interest quickly if an answer is boring or not well presented. Good luck! NB: My first novel titled ‘Our Feet Were Soft in Flowers’ will be published soon.

In a writer’s sense or, like, for school? I’ll just reply in the writer’s sense… If you meant for school tell me and I’ll do another answer for that. Thanks! .`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`.`. Well, first of all, you have to know what you’re doing. I mean, sure, you can always just type random letters and put spaces inbetween… But like anyone’s going to read that! I write a lot, so here’s something I can tell you: do NOT overuse words. Like, read a sentence from one of my old works; “Mom seemed kind of scared, and I did, too. The situation seemed hopeless. But, for some reason, Nurse Molly didn’t seem scared. She seemed brave. She looked the humanoid in the eyes, and it seemed pretty surprised that she faced it.” You must’ve gotten tired reading that, right? My little ten year-old self apparently liked the word seem(ed). There’s a way you can fix a sentence/paragraph/chapter if you feel you’ve been using a word too much. It’s easy. Just either find a synomyn for that word, or phrase it differently, like how we all do when we can’t remember how to spell(lol). You can easily search up synonyms on Google, and find sites that tell you synonyms of words… For example, this one.  If replaced with synonyms: “Mom hinted that she was kind of scared, and I did, too. The situation suggested hopelessness. But, for some reason, Nurse Molly didn’t seem scared. She showed nearly very sign of bravery. She looked the humanoid in the eyes, and it looked pretty surprised that she faced it.” That sounds better, now doesn’t it? It’s okay to still keep the word you overused in there once or twice, as long as the others got replaced. You wanted to rephrase instead? Just re-write the paragraph underneath the current one, trying to use a different view on what’s happening, maybe change the order of saying things. For example, you might change this: “Mom seemed kind of scared, and I did, too. The situation seemed hopeless. But, for some reason, Nurse Molly didn’t seem scared. She seemed brave. She looked the humanoid in the eyes, and it seemed pretty surprised that she faced it.” Into this: “The situation displayed our very real loss of hope… Yet Nurse Molly stepped forwards, and bravely faced the humanoid, who drew back the slightest bit in surprise. Mom and I were too scared to move, let alone breathe, as the nurse and inhuman stared into each others eyes.” Sounds a bit better, huh? Kinda. You can also get yourself really into the story. If you’re not, you’re gonna get bored quickly, and that’ll often lead to blanking out. Make sure each character has their own unique way of talking/doing things and that should keep you busy. When intruducing a new character, describe them in detail… That should add a lot of words. Also describe new scenes in detail. Always take note of the character’s facial expressions, or at least hint to what their faces look like. This will probably give your reader a good view on what is happening. Make sure your characters have their flaws, and make those come out every once in a while. That should make up more words because more events will take place that way. Maybe have some bad event happen to a character and describe the way they feel. Maybe have two of your characters confess to one another, that’ll make for interesting topics to write about. …Or even have a character talk about their backstory. Hope this helped! Also, sorry if I got carried away…
